'''Éadig Béo Þu''' is an [[Old English]] song written by [[J.R.R. Tolkien]], to be sung to the tune of ''Twinkle, Twinkle, Little Star''. It is published as the 14th song in ''[[Songs for the Philologists]]'' in [[1936]].

The song is reprinted with Modern English translation "Good Luck to You" in ''[[The Road to Middle-earth]]'' by [[T.A. Shippey]]. Corrections made by Tolkien himself (after the printing of the ''Songs'') are noted below.

==The song==
<poem style="font-style:italic; margin-left:20px;">
'''Éadig Béo Þu'''

Éadig béo þu, góda mann!
Éadig béo þu, léofe wif!
Langre lisse ic þe ann —
hafa lof and líke líf!
Hé þe hér swa sáre swanc,
rúna rǽdde' and fyrngewrit,
hál beo hé, on sálum wlanc,
halde láre' and wís gewit!

Éadig béo we eft swa nú!
Dréam ne dréose, drync genóg
flówe on fullum síb swa iú —
fyllaþ wǽge, fyllaþ cróg!
Byrla! Byrla! medu scenc! <ref group=note>[JRRT corr. from:] Byrla! byrla! medu briht —</ref>
Dóm is feor þeah dóm sie strang.
Swinc forlǽt and géot ús drenc! <ref group=note>[JRRT corr. from:] Swinc tomorgen, drinc toniht!</ref>
Lust is lýtel, earfoþ lang.

Uton singan scírne sang,
herian Beorc and byrcen cynn,
láre' and láreow, leornungmann —
sie ús sǽl and hǽl and wynn!
Ác sceal feallan on þæt fýr
lustes, léafes, lífes wan!
Beorc sceal ágan langne tír,
bréme glǽme glengan wang!
</poem>

==Translation by Shippey==
<poem style="font-style:italic; margin-left:20px; margin-right:20px;">
'''Good Luck to You'''

Good luck to you, good man, and to you, dear woman. I give you lasting joy, have praise and pleasant life. He who worked you here so hard, expounded runes and ancient texts, may he be happy too, merry at his feasts, and keep up good sense and learning.

May we be happy later as we are now, may joy not fail, and drink enough flow in the cups in times to come as times gone by — fill the cups and fill the pitchers! Waiter, waiter, give us mead! Doom is far though doom be strong, give up work and pour us drink. <ref group=note>There are three versions of the 5th and 7th lines of this stanza. The first (as printed in the ''Songs'') is ''Byrla! byrla! medu briht ... Swinc tomorgen, drinc toniht!'', or ‘Waiter! waiter! bright mead ... work tomorrow, drink tonight!’. Tolkien rejected this because ‘''briht'' is not an OE form’. The second is ''Byrla medu! Byrla wín! ... Scenc nu his and scenc nu mín'', or ‘Serve mead! Serve wine! ... Now give him his and give me mine’. The third and last is given above.</ref> Joy is little and labour long.

Let's sing a cheerful song, praise the Birch and birch's race, the teacher, the student and the subject, may we all have health and joy and happiness. The oak will fall into the fire, losing joy and leaf and life. The birch shall keep its glory long, shine in splendour over the bright plain. 
</poem>
